title: British-Australian blogger and boyfriend released from Iran prison
text:
Australian foreign minister Marise Payne has confirmed that Jolie King and Mark Firkin have been ‘released and returned’ (Picture: AAPIMAGE/AFP via Getty Images)

A British-Australian blogger and her Australian boyfriend have been released from an Iran prison in a suspected prisoner swap deal, while another British-Australian woman remains held.

Australian foreign minister Marise Payne said that it was ‘with some enormous relief’ that she could announce Jolie King and Mark Firkin had been ‘released and returned’ and all charges against them dropped after a three-month detention.

At the same time, Iran’s state TV reported that an Iranian scientist, Reza Dehbashi, who was detained for 13 months in Australia over purchasing a defense system for his country from the United States, had returned home.

There has been no immediate acknowledgement from Iranian officials or in the country’s state media of the couple’s release and no confirmation from either side that a prisoner swap has taken place so far.

Advertisement

Iranian TV said that the Australian judiciary had planned to send Dehbashi to the U.S. but that he was released through Tehran’s diplomatic efforts.

Miss King and Mr Firkin were detained in Tehran for spying earlier this year after they reportedly flew a drone without a permit over military areas and unauthorised zones, according to Tasnim news agency’s quote from judiciary spokesman Gholamhossein Esmaili.

The couple – who had posted updates of their trip across Asia to their thousands of social media followers – is said to be in ‘good health and in good spirits’ after being released and reunited with their families.

In a statement that thanked the Australian government for helping secure their release, they said: ‘We are extremely happy and relieved to be safely back in Australia with those we love.

Jolie King and Mark Firkin are said to be in ‘good health and in good spirits’ after their release (Picture: AAPIMAGE)

British-Australian academic Dr Kylie Moore-Gilbert is still being held in Iran (Picture: PA)

‘While the past few months have been very difficult, we know it has also been tough for those back home who have been worried for us.’

They requested privacy as they seek to ‘get back to (their) normal lives.’

However, Ms Payne also confirmed that Cambridge-educated academic Kylie Moore-Gilbert is still in Tehran’s notorious Evin Prison, which is well-known for holding high-profile foreign and dual-national prisoners.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Dr Moore-Gilbert, who was a lecturer in Islamic Studies at Melbourne University, has been in jail for almost a year after reportedly being handed a 10-year sentence for spying.

Ms Payne said the situation was ‘very complex’ and that ‘very long–term negotiations’ were taking place to secure her release.

‘She has been detained for some considerable time, and has faced the Iranian legal system and has been convicted and sentenced,’ she said, adding the government did not accept the spying charges against her.

The University of Melbourne’s website lists Dr Moore-Gilbert on its ‘Find an expert’ page as a lecturer at the university’s Asia Institute.

Ms Payne said ‘very long–term negotiations’ were being held to secure Dr Moore-Gilbert’s release (Picture: AFP via Getty Images)

Jailed British mother Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe with her husband Richard Ratcliffe and their daughter Gabriella (Picture: PA)

It states that she ‘specialises in Middle Eastern politics, with a particular focus on the Arab Gulf states,’ and adds that she had published work on the 2011 Arab uprisings, authoritarian governance and on the role of new media technologies in political activism.

Dr David Malet, who served on Dr Moore-Gilbert’s dissertation committee, has described her as a ‘wonderful person and a serious scholar, not a spy’.

A British-Iranian mother-of-one named Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, 41, is also currently held in Evin prison after being handed a five-year sentence in 2016 for spying.

Mrs Zaghari-Ratcliffe, who denies the charges, wrote an open letter this week that revealed she was to send her daughter home to the UK to start school.

Advertisement

Five-year-old Gabriella had been living with her grandparents in Tehran and had visited her mum at least once a week since her arrest.

However, it is now hoped that she will be back in London before Christmas after her parents applied to Iranian authorities for an exit visa.

In a letter smuggled out of Tehran prison and published by the Centre for Human Rights in Iran, Mrs Zaghari-Ratcliffe wrote: ‘In the near future my baby will leave me to go with her father and start school in the UK.

‘It will be daunting trip for her travelling and for me left behind.

‘And the authorities who hold me will watch on unmoved at the injustice of separation. That first day of school not for me.’

Mrs Zaghari-Ratcliffe’s letter was named ‘heart-breaking’ by foreign secretary Dominic Raab who said her detainment was ‘unjustifiable and unacceptable’.

description: A British-Australian blogger and her Australian boyfriend have been released from Iran's Evin prison, but other Brits remain held.
